New Records: Dawid Malan scored 140, his highest ODI score, and England’s highest score in a World Cup match was 364 for nine.
Key Match Events: Dawid Malan scored an unbeaten 140 off 107 balls featuring five sixes and 16 fours.
Reece Topley took four wickets for 43 runs.
Mark Wood took 2 wickets for 29 runs.
Chris Woakes conceded 34 runs in his first four overs.
Pre-Game Insights: None explicitly mentioned in the article.
Post-Match Reflections: Chris Woakes’s efforts with the new ball were expensive, but the game was effectively won by Malan’s century.
Jonny Bairstow surpassed Graham Gooch to become England’s all-time highest scorer at World Cups with 159 runs in two matches.
England’s middle order struggled, scoring less than 20 runs apiece.
There is much more to come from this side but at least the outlook – like the net run rate – is positive.
Miscellaneous Highlights: A violent storm shook Dharamsala shortly before the match.
Malan’s final 40 runs came off 16 balls, demonstrating his ability to accelerate when needed.
Others: Chris Woakes’s four overs in the first innings cost 34 runs.
Bangladesh’s only real ambition was damage management once Topley and Wood took key wickets.
